None be brave enough to mine ‘em though, ‘cause o’ the coldness an’ the evil things that wander the place… the only piece o’ Vorgo gold known to exist outside the mountains was carried out by the single survivor of a doomed minin’ expedition, the rest of ‘em bein’ taken by slow, painful starvation before the evil mountain Winds made somethin’ unspeakable out of ‘em.

Panteleon was an old Knight o'Quenelles, where those Bretonnian landlubbers are in cahoots with the Elves of the neighbourin’ forest. They say ‘e wore a piece o’Athel Loren amber round ‘is neck - imbued with powers it was, could even bring life to dead flesh! Sadly, 'twas lost when the fool sailed to the Vampire Coast to take on a shoal o' Prometheans… Panteleon slaughtered ‘em, but the crabs eventually dragged ‘im off ‘is ship an' pincered 'im to pieces. But 'is ship, the Lamprey, survived.

Thar be no sailor alive who don’t know the tale of Cap’n Vangheist. A Wizard named Albrechtus von Zeich had paid ‘im in ingots o’ the purest gold to provide passage through the Sea o’Chaos, but when von Zeich refused the cap’n’s ambitions to get the secrets of immortality from the Realm o’Chaos itself, he got shot. Sailin’ on right out o’ the mortal plane, Vangheist an’ ‘is crew left their bodies an’ material things behind, includin’ the ship’s cursed cargo - its fate remains unknown...

The magic that took ol’ Nyklaus von Carstein out o’ Sylvania needed more than just some powerful juju an’ a titanic will… some magic trinkets were also used to bolster ‘is energies, one bein’ the mysterious Stone o’Schwartzhafen. They say it contains the souls of the great fallen warriors o’Sylvania from afore the von Carsteins’ time. Alas, the stone got lost after the Bloody Reaver had an ‘ole ripped in ‘er hull by the Heldenhammer's broadside, tragically spillin’ some booty into the sea.

Reik-Admiral Houghhoff possesses one of the three verses of the fabled Lost Sea Shanty, and by exceeding his infamy you have provoked his ire. He is now sailing the seas, determined to hunt you down and reclaim his place. You must put an end to this pirate once and for all, and in doing so take the verse from him!

Fhiron Wavemaker possesses one of the three verses of the fabled Lost Sea Shanty, and by exceeding his infamy you have provoked his ire. He is now sailing the seas, determined to hunt you down and reclaim his place. You must put an end to this pirate once and for all, and in doing so take the verse from him!

Barron von Heastie possesses one of the three verses of the fabled Lost Sea Shanty, and by exceeding his infamy you have provoked his ire. He is now sailing the seas, determined to hunt you down and reclaim his place. You must put an end to this pirate once and for all, and in doing so take the verse from him!
Defeat the pirates that possess the First Shanty Verse for a chance to steal it. Specifically defeating their faction leader in combat, or forming an alliance, will guarantee you get it.
Defeat the pirates that possess the Second Shanty Verse for a chance to steal it. Specifically defeating their faction leader in combat, or forming an alliance, will guarantee you get it.
Defeat the pirates that possess the Final Shanty Verse for a chance to steal it. Specifically defeating their faction leader in combat, or forming an alliance, will guarantee you get it.

The fleet grows and the curs of this world learn to fear your name, but there are still those who oppose us. Send these fools to the depths - the Maelstrom will chew them up and spit them out with a more favourable disposition, my lord.

Luthor Harkon had been looking for a way to restore his connection to the Winds of Magic for decades. Many years ago, he disturbed an ancient chamber sealed with some powerful glyphs, resulting in his mind being shattered into a dozen different facets which left him teetering on the brink of insanity. Luthor thought it likely that the glyphs were of Slann origin, concluding that the best chance he had to undo his impairments was to find powerful artefacts from the same source.
\The Slann – a powerful species of Lizardmen with an unparalleled mastery over the Sorcerous arts – are known to use many enchanted totems and trinkets of gold to serve their indecipherable purposes. The best chance of finding one was to search the most ancient ruins of the long-abandoned cities and towns of Lustria and beyond, where the Slann were most likely to have left their mark. After searching countless ruins, Luthor and his pirate horde came across a shackled slave claiming to have been a former soldier of the Empire. He told Luthor that he had recently been part of an expeditionary force that found a chest of embossed Slann Gold, but on their way back to camp they were ambushed by a vast Lizardmen army, the largest he had ever seen. The soldier narrowly escaped with his life, but everyone in his troop was slaughtered and the Lizardmen made off back to Lustria with their gold.

Clearly this hoard is of great importance to the Lizardmen for them to have brought such a force to take it back – there must be more to this gold than its monetary value alone. Luthor can see his goal clearly now, his mind yearning to be repaired. He needs to gather his minions, return to Lustria, and attack these cold-blooded freaks!

localised_title: The Rise of the Red Crests: Apostles of War
localised_description: Blessed are the red-crested believers, infused with Sotek’s everlasting spirit, imbued with staunch resilience, propelled by the unwavering zeal of the Serpent-God’s Chosen.

localised_title: The Rise of the Red Crests: Exodus
localised_description: Against the tide of non-believers, Sotek’s red-crested faithful shall emerge as his champions, to go forth and make disciples of all the Old Ones’ children, beseeching them in the name of the Serpent-God.

localised_title: The Skaven War: Our Blessed Lands
localised_description: Only after the bastions of the Old Ones are reclaimed, the incursions of the Rodent-God’s defiling minions upon the land called Lustria shall be borne by an epic struggle…

localised_title: The Skaven War: The Great Purge
localised_description: When the evil rat-spawn set foot on these sacred shores to deliver their plague and pestilence, the time of their great purge shall be at hand…

localised_title: The Skaven War: Wrath of the Jungle
localised_description: Once the Great Serpent is beseeched, the evocation of His slithering servants in the jungle shall see the enemies of the Old Ones’ children fall victim to His vengeance…

localised_title: The Skaven War: The Great Serpent’s Due
localised_description: The Great Serpent shall have His day, for He is the vanquisher of all rodent-kind, honoured and invoked through rightful tribute, that shall see the rivers of the mighty Amaxon run crimson with blood…
Behold Sotek, a serpent of such unimaginable size and appetite that he shall swallow the Rat-God himself, whole, and spend a thousand years digesting him, crushing him within his coils!

A stunted warmblood is known to be stealing from our kin, plundering our stockpiles of raw materials. His wanton pilfering hinders our ability to complete sequences central to the Great Plan – Lustria must be rid of him!

One of the warmbloods has been observed revivifying the wounded of his invading kin, reversing much of our cohorts’ hard work on the battlefield and faltering our progress in eradicating them. His elimination will be hugely favourable.

A cohort of foolish warmbloods once discovered the City of Mists and dared enter its gates, all but one being unceremoniously slaughtered by its mighty guardians. The one survivor’s knowledge of Xlanhuapec makes him a grave threat that must be destroyed.

One of the foreign invaders prowls our jungles’ canopies with surprising aptitude. This light-footed huntress poses a great threat to us, having already slain dozens of our gargantuan kin for reasons unknown – she must be expulsed.

Lustria’s jungles burn. Its temple-cities crumble. Under Markus Wulfhart’s command, the Emperor’s forces have wreaked havoc in the New World, wantonly plundering the lucrative holdings of the lizard-beasts while sweeping aside all foes sent against them. But now, the most monstrous of them of all has been roused.\n\nWulfhart's scouts have informed him that the creature known as the Spirit of the Jungle has been sighted somewhere in the vicinity of Itza. The Huntsmarshal has caught the scent; this will be his toughest hunt yet.

One by one, Nakai fought off the so-called great hunters in cahoots with the Huntsmarshal. And one by one, they fled into the jungle like the warm-blooded cowards they are. Nakai correctly sensed they would be back for more, and now the chief warmblood himself, Markus Wulfhart, takes to the field with them. Lustria’s future hangs in the balance, for why else would Nakai be so compelled to act? This conflict ends now!

What a gods-forsaken place this truly is. It seems that not a day goes by without the news of some horrible tropical disease striking some poor settler down. The most innocuous cut or scratch sustained here can become horribly infected within hours, making every trek into the jungle a highly risky endeavour indeed.

Perhaps by fate, word has reached me of a mysterious individual who shadows the Empire’s troops in the deep jungle, patching up the wounds of the gravely injured left behind following skirmishes with the lizards. Men thought to be well within Morr’s deathly embrace have been mysteriously brought back from the brink by someone who clearly has advanced medical training, with even the most horrendous injuries cleaned, disinfected, and stitched as if by the hands of the most highly-trained physician in all of the Empire. Our very own injured relate to me their encounters with this healer, not remembering much other than glimpses of a necklace of fangs – trophies perhaps?

I have been in few environments more treacherous to man than Lustria; it goes without saying that for us to endure here, we should somehow reach out to this ‘medic’ and persuade them to join our cause.

Hertwig van Hal is an intriguing individual. He bears the surname of a well-known ancient lineage of Witch Hunters, but for reasons unknown to me he seems rather ashamed of it. When I brought it up he responded angrily, claiming his vocation as a Witch Hunter was not of his choosing. He then quickly changed the subject, revealing that he was a master physician of Altdorf and insisted I address him as ‘Herr Doctor’. It truly beguiles me why a physician from Altdorf is carrying out Witch Hunter duties in Lustria, but I am not one to poke about in another man’s private affairs.\n\nThere is certainly much more to Herr Doctor which perhaps in time he will reveal on his own volition, but right now he has temporarily left camp. Before leaving, he told me he intends to track down some information about one particular Vampire he has been searching for called Alistair the Red. He has given me assurances that I cannot help him with this particular task and that he will return soon.

In getting to know Herr Doctor better, I’ve discovered that he is a most conflicted man. He is ruthlessly obsessed with destroying Vampires, but is also a skilful healer with astounding convalescent skills. I felt I had built up enough of a rapport to bring up the subject of his famous lineage once again.

With a deep sigh, Hertwig explained his intense hate for the van Hal name, for his ambition was always to preserve life and not to chase destruction. For him, the van Hals would never be innocent of their progenitor’s sins and he wanted nothing to do with them. "A man can try to avoid his destiny as much as he wants," he added, "but in the end it will always find him." He would elaborate no further. 

The next day, he invoked me to continue helping him with his mission to track down Alistair the Red. He says the best way to draw attention from a Vampire Pirate is to raid their lands and waters, so that is what we will do. It is certainly not without a touch of irony that we are probably about to steal from pirates.

Herr Doctor continues to be driven by a strong desire to destroy this creature of the night he refers to as Alistair the Red. Having observed Hertwig slay dozens of Vampires up to now, it is clear he gains no pleasure from it, but at the same time carries out Witch Hunter duties with the aptitude of one who was born to do so – like a true van Hal. Though my curiosity threatens to overcome me, I have resisted asking further questions about the history of this man I have befriended. It seems there is no time for it anyway, as Herr Doctor now wants us to mobilise against The Awakening, and immediately.\n\nThose who know anything about the area say the place is a husk of an old colony that was settled many years ago, but was left haunted, derelict, and overrun by the Undead. There is a lot of unknown history there, but Hertwig is convinced its winding streets and deep catacombs harbour the creature that he seeks to destroy.  A direct assault on this place seems dangerous, but I am a man of my word and Herr Doctor assures us he is very close to achieving his goal.

In the time I’ve spent helping van Hal I have gotten to know him well, learning that his story is one of great tragedy not unlike my own.

In his early days Hertwig was a physician of Altdorf and distanced himself from the van Hal name, hating its connotations. He cared little for the affairs of Witch Hunters, dedicating his life only to the practise of medicine and his beloved fiancé Matilda. One evening, a red-haired corpse was brought to his surgery with a stake mysteriously plunged through its heart. The young, naïve doctor removed the stake during the examination and later that night found the creature with its fangs buried in Matilda's neck. He desperately fought the vile monster off before it fled, but it was too late. To prevent Matilda from rising from the dead, he had no choice but to stab her through the heart and remove her head. Beset by anguish and grief, van Hal felt he had no choice but to dedicate himself to the destruction of creatures of the night.

With the red-haired Vampire that killed his beloved now slain, he is grateful for my help and guidance and will serve the expedition indefinitely.

In the time I’ve spent helping Herr Doctor I have gotten to know him well, learning that his story is one of great tragedy not unlike my own.

In his early days Hertwig was a physician of Altdorf and distanced himself from the van Hal name, hating its connotations. He cared little for the affairs of Witch Hunters, dedicating his life only to the practise of medicine and his beloved fiancé Matilda. One evening, a red-haired corpse was brought to his surgery with a stake mysteriously plunged through its heart. The young, naïve doctor removed the stake during the examination and later that night found the creature with its fangs buried in Matilda's neck. He desperately fought the vile monster off before it fled, but it was too late. To prevent Matilda from rising from the dead, he had no choice but to stab her through the heart and remove her head. Beset by anguish and grief, van Hal felt he had no choice but to dedicate himself to the destruction of creatures of the night.

With the red-haired Vampire that killed his beloved now slain, he is grateful for my help and guidance and will serve the expedition indefinitely.

The colonists have long known about Lizardmen mining convoys that regularly travel along established trails in the deep jungle like clockwork. They transport some sort of glossy black raw material that resembles obsidian, the dense metal that the Wizards of home know all too well for its anti-magic properties. There was some concern when these convoy movements inexplicably stopped, perhaps now taking different routes if not ceasing altogether. I was unconcerned, but apparently the lizards don’t change their ways without very good reason. To appease the colonists, I sent out an expedition to investigate the old trails and they soon returned with a captive – a Skink, one of the convoy overseers.

When our Saurian translator asked the skittish creature about the black material, it held its forked tongue. Further ‘prodding’ with my hunting knife made the creature reveal something about a "short, bearded warmblood" that had been repeatedly stealing from their convoys, forcing them to change their routes.

What is a Dwarf doing this far from the Spine of Sotek mountains? This Dawi is either incredibly brave or incredibly stupid to be harassing the Lizardmen on their own turf, but is getting away with it somehow. Credit where credit’s due…

It is truly astonishing how this Dawi Engineer has been able to survive out in the wild on his solo forays against the Lizardmen's convoys, but it is clearly down to his own ingenuity. A keen and talented inventor, Jorek seems to have all sorts of survivalist equipment at his disposal, all designed and built himself. He is very secretive about his past, revealing little more than the location of his previous home back in the Old World, the great Dwarf port of Barak Varr.\n\nIt seems that something in Jorek’s earlier life clearly irks him, which really isn’t all that surprising – Dwarfs feel all wrongdoings committed against them as if they had only just happened. With wild eyes he tells me that he is destined for great things, but must "rebuild his reputation, one invention at a time". Though he appears sceptical that we can really help him, he sees value in the protection the expedition can provide on his travels through Lustria. He has also suggested we gather some resources for some new inventions he thinks may prove useful to him and the expedition.

I am amazed by this Dwarf’s ambition and enthusiasm for invention. He seems to find a use for any kind of material he can find and gets excited about all the unique resources we come across. This obsession with metallurgy and mineralogy has made it clearer to me why he is here – the Lustrian jungle is one of the most unexplored places in the known world, offering many mysterious raw materials with strange and amazing properties to a tinkerer like Jorek.\n\nGradually, the Master Engineer has also become more open about his past. Given his chosen surroundings, I was surprised to discover that he was once a great shipbuilder but had been shunned and ousted by the Engineers' Guild back in Barak Varr. According to him, his contemporaries considered him a threat because of his intellectual brilliance, although I have a feeling there are elements to this story he has not revealed. It is perhaps unwise to probe any further; I can never hope to understand the confusing, stubborn, grudge-holding ways of the Dawi anyway. As long as Jorek continues to help the expedition, we will continue to supply him with the materials he needs.

Jorek has revealed to me that he has been working on something big. He described it as a "masterpiece of gyro-powered flight", a flying machine he claims will be better than any Gyrocopter built by his kin anywhere in the world. All he needs to complete its assembly is a chunk of a rare metal called 'obsinite', a form of Lustrian obsidian used by the Lizardmen that is harder and more durable than steel. With the Lizardmen's mining convoys having now changed their routes to avoid Jorek’s thieving attentions, we’ll have to find a different source of the metal. He tells me he has a hidden stockpile collected from his previous smash-'n'-grab attacks, located on the Volcanic Islands off the east coast of Lustria. Alternatively, he also knows of a consignment of obsinite heading north towards the Ancient City of Quintex.\n\nBy the sounds of it, the flying machine Jorek intends to build would be a very welcome addition to the expedition's armoury. This may very well be worth the effort!

In return for helping him obtain all the raw materials he has desired thus far, Jorek has accepted a permanent position with my expedition. This is most fortunate, for he has proven himself a valuable member of the hunting party, whose unique skills make him integral to our mission. More than that, Jorek has become a loyal friend. One day, as we enjoyed a barrel of Bugman’s together, he revealed to me the rest of his sorry story.

Once a member of the Cragbrow Clan of Barak Varr, Jorek was commissioned to design new steamships for his throng, but utilised methods of engineering that eschewed Dwarf traditions. He knew there was great potential in his designs regardless of the techniques used to develop them, but could never see them through to completion due to sabotage by his jealous, ultra-traditionalist peers. In the end, Jorek was ousted from the Engineers' Guild and left for good. Truly, the Dwarfs are a strange lot!

Now with the freedom and raw materials to develop any invention he chooses, I have never seen a happier Dwarf in all my life. I have little doubt that in time the potential brainchildren of this brilliant inventor will help turn the tide of our struggle here in Lustria.

localised_title: I. The Ghost in the Jungle
localised_description:
The colonists speak of something strange living in the nearby jungles. They say it is not of the lizards, nor of the ratmen that infest this continent, but something else; a "ghost" they call it. Part of me thinks this gods-forsaken place drives some men to hallucinations, but today a hunting party returned with a curious tale. They had been tracking a wild Bastiladon whose carcass would have provided much sustenance for the colonists, and had trapped the great beast in a bog. They claim that as they moved in for the kill, it was unexpectedly struck down by an arrow propelled through the thick jungle canopy directly into one of its eyes.

Such frightening huntsmanship could only be supernatural. In this flora-covered terrain, it is almost impossible to hit a moving Bastiladon’s weak points from range as the men described. Furthermore, they claim they were then threatened by a mysterious, hooded figure in the trees above them, a sorrowful voice of a woman telling them "whosoever approaches my bounty will share its fate".

Perhaps this is the "ghost" the colonists speak of? Whatever it is, to kill a Bastiladon in such a way requires a level of precision far exceeding that of any huntsman I’ve ever met.

I have met a few of the elusive fey folk of Athel Loren, and in my early dealings with Kalara it certainly appears she is typical of her kind. On the rare occasions in the past when my hunting expeditions unwittingly led me into the Wood Elves’ realm, I found them to be standoffish and determinedly detached from the outside world – almost aggressively so. Those familiar with the Asrai know better than to trespass upon their hunting grounds, for they are considered to be some of the most lethal hunters in the known world. We are extremely fortunate to have brought a Waystalker into our ranks, regardless of how aloof she may be.\n\nKalara told me that she has been in Lustria for quite some time. The beast she seeks does not prowl these lands alone though and bringing it down will take some fight, which is why she requested our assistance. For a Waystalker to admit that a quarry is beyond her talent confirms what an incredibly dangerous monster it must be. I gave her assurances that I would see this hunt through, but for now we await more information regarding the beast’s whereabouts.

Kalara has been part of the expedition for quite some time now. She seems restless to slay this beast, but knows little about its actual nature. I find it curious as to why she seeks a quarry which is largely a mystery to her… but in truth I am simply glad to have her strength added to our own, so see no need to push the question. We are mobilising now anyway, as news has reached camp that a treasure-seeking convoy of about fifty-or-so men disappeared into some nearby ruins. Kalara insisted she investigate and came back describing a grisly scene. Little was left of the mutilated men, she said, and she is convinced it is connected to the beast we are hunting.\n\nThough I respect Kalara greatly, I feel she has not been entirely forthcoming with us. She might not be lying about what she has seen this time, but I do believe she is withholding something about the motives for her Lustrian hunt. For this reason, I’ve decided to take the expedition and investigate this ruin myself.

I started having reservations about the true nature of the beast Kalara is pursuing, and even considered calling off this hunt – but then she revealed something quite astounding.

It is her sincere belief that the beast she hunts contains the reincarnated soul of her dead lover. She explained that as punishment from the one called Kurnous, the Elven God of the Hunt, Kalara’s beloved is in an endless cycle of life and death, always coming back as a murderous beast after it is slain. She has killed several versions of the beast before, and is determined to end the cycle once and for all, so her love may finally pass into the afterlife. She believes almost obsessively that Kurnous is testing her, for she always finds that the lost soul of her lover passes into a more unkillable beast than the one before it.

Truly, the Elven gods are stranger than those of men. Out of empathy for Kalara’s loss, I have decided to continue helping her for now. We must cast our net out wide and interrogate the Dark Ones to the north as well as the lizards to the south to see what they know of this beast.

I confronted Kalara last night, hunter to hunter, urging her to give up this futile mission. To my surprise, she agreed, but implored me to help her with one final task. I accepted on the sole condition she tell me everything.

Kalara revealed she was once a princess of Wydrioth, a High Realm of Athel Loren. Her lover Atherin was a Wild Rider of Kurnous, the personal guard of Athel Loren’s king. Atherin violated his oath to sever all worldly ties, persisting in his relationship with Kalara and even revealing his order’s hallowed secrets to her. Kurnous vengefully transformed Atherin into a mighty stag before cruelly leading Kalara to unwittingly hunt it down. Discovering the stag’s true nature, Kalara eventually learned of Atherin’s cursed fate of eternal reincarnation as a beast.

She had also recently been visited in her dreams by the goddess Isha, mother of the Elven race and consort to Kurnous himself. A great privilege, she said, for Isha is usually forbidden to have any contact with her worldly children. The goddess offered Kalara another route to freeing her lover's soul – instead of further destruction, she must make a worldly display of love and construct a shrine directly on the banks of Itza’s fabled Emerald Pools.

It caught my attention recently to hear of a swordsman who had become army-less after miraculously escaping a slaughter at the hands of the lizard-beasts. A possible recruit? If my memory serves me correctly, he had arrived months earlier on a galleon that was flying a flag of a Bretonnian dukedom unknown to me, though I know little of the Land of Chivalry. He had disembarked with a group of men who looked vaguely Knightly in appearance, but it was unclear whether they were individuals of any important political status. Their retinue was quite poorly equipped, as were they themselves. After buying what additional weapons and supplies they could from the colonists, they foolhardily headed straight into the jungle.

Whether out of prudence of curiosity, I had them followed and watched. Unsurprisingly, word eventually returned that the Bretonnians were ill-prepared for their foray, losing half their retinue to disease and attacks before stumbling into the mists surrounding the ancient temple-city of Xlanhuapec. Thinking it was uninhabited, they attempted to plunder the city but instead suffered a catastrophic slaughter at the hands of the Lizardmen in a painfully predictable ambush.

The one survivor – this swordsman – had somehow fought himself out of the trap and was still out there.

The Bretonnian noble Rodrik L’Anguille appears to be a man of great physical strength and fortitude. He must be, for he has witnessed many terrible things while on his doomed journey. He has told me stories of men being swallowed up by monstrous things lurking in the waist-deep bogs they waded through on the trek, only to be spat out again in a spray of bloody gore. And then of the slaughter at Xlanhuapec itself; how he and his men observed the temple-city to be totally uninhabited as they entered, getting all the way into the central plaza before being set upon by a swarm of twelve foot tall reptilian monsters with daggers for teeth. Though he had fought out of his skin to survive and escape, in reality many of his men had fell trying to protect him.\n\nRodrik clearly yearns for vengeance, but there is also a downtroddenness to his character which I think goes far deeper than just the recent loss of his men. Maybe it is the reason why he came here in the first place, which he hasn’t really talked about? Right now, Xlanhuapec is in range for a potentially successful assault which needs to be capitalised upon without delay.

localised_title: III. A Bretonnian Without a Home
localised_description: After avenging the death of his men at Xlanhuapec, I have realised more and more that Rodrik still bears within him a great resentment of something deeper. The only thing he has revealed thus far is that there are those back home in his dukedom of Anguille who would sooner see him dead than allow him to return. However, I have developed too much respect for the man just to ask about what sounds like a complicated past. After all, many an ill-advised adventurer has come to seek riches in this place for one reason or another, most of whom underestimate how terrifying a place Lustria really is.\n\n The galleons that steadily trickle into the New World colonies constantly bring greedy fools from the Old World, who have unwisely braved the perilous crossing of the Great Ocean just for an opportunity to plunder cities they are not sure even exist. Of course, they all become lizard-feed in the end – but not Rodrik. He may very well be one of these greedy fools, but to have faced the Lizardmen and survived marks him out as a warrior we could really do with having around regardless of his past indiscretions.

To help our friend Rodrik I have ordered the expedition to march towards Pox Marsh. There, he claims, we will intercept the assassins who wish him dead before they even know what hit them. One evening, as we pitched camp for the night along the route, Rodrik pulled me away from the campfire for a private word. With a deep sadness to his tone, he revealed that Lord Tudual – the unsavoury individual who had ordered his death – is actually the duke of Anguille, Rodrik’s homeland. But even more shocking is the fact that this Duke Tudual is actually Rodrik’s father. So Rodrik is a prince of Anguille! He went on to explain that he is an 'unfavoured' heir, seen as a threat to Duke Tudual’s desired successor, Rodrik’s younger brother.\n\nThe reason why Rodrik came here with only a ragtag force in the first place has now become clear – Duke Tudual had sent his son to Lustria under the guise of wanting him to prove himself, but in reality was counting on him perishing. It seems the duke underestimated both Rodrik's skill as swordsman and his will to live. I have reassured Rodrik that he has nothing to fear and together we shall vanquish these would-be assassins.

localised_title: V. A Prince Born of a Pauper
localised_description:
What a sorry state of affairs this truly is for Prince Rodrik. We dealt with Duke Tudual’s assassins without issue, but only time will tell if this will be the last attempt to prevent his son from returning to Anguille. Rodrik himself seems uninterested in returning anyway – he tells me he has no intention of claiming power in a land he now feels no attachment to, for the jungle has become his home.

The last piece of Rodrik story – the reason why his father wants him dead – had eluded me until recently, simply because Rodrik had kept it secret. Now I know why, for it is a source of great shame for him. Though Rodrik was his father’s eldest son, his mother was a commoner who was Duke Tudual’s peasant concubine. Fearing he would have no other sons, the duke recognised and brought Rodrik into his household from birth, but when Rodrik’s younger brother was unexpectedly born of the duke’s lawful wife, Rodrik was foresaken.

Prince Rodrik remains the rightful heir to the dukedom of Anguille, and as long as he lives it is feasible that Duke Tudual will attempt to remove him by sending assassins once again. As always, we must stay vigilant on his behalf.
The desert mountain Dwarfs are said to possess the banner of Jean Claude Sartre. Perhaps a trade can be arranged that might persuade them to part with it?
The desert mountain Dwarfs are said to possess the banner of Jean Claude Sartre. Diplomacy is no longer an option – we must act.
The banner of Pierre d'Arden is said to be lost to history. However, any Bretonnian subjects wish to recreate this most beautiful of banners, so let us give them a reason to do so.

When its location was last noted, the banner of Rene de Cartes was in territory controlled by the Undead. We should cleanse their foul scourge from the land and retrieve this most noble of standards from their vile, skeletal hands.
Capturing this region would send the right kind of message to the Tomb Kings.

The dark pyramid squats like a predatory crab over the Great Mortis Delta, a nightmare testament to the Great Betrayer and the unholy stain of Undeath. The Southlands can never know virtue so long as the dead still infest this cursed edifice. There must come a righteous cleansing!

This perverse monument to the twisted, ungodly schemes of Nagash, he who blighted this world with the fathomless heresy of Necromancy, can stand no more. A virtuous Bretonnian must wrest Arkhan's infernal spire from cold, Undead hands, and at long last restore purity, light and true faith to a land that has too long worshipped the Lord of Death.
The foul Orcs are truly a scourge on any land they set foot in, spreading like a belligerent plague. Repanse must show them that their presence here will not be tolerated.

As the current Drachau of Hag Graef, Malus Darkblade is not only the preferred servant of Malekith, but also the general of his armies. It is not only the Druchii military hierarchy that compels Malus to ruthlessly exert Naggaroth’s influence across the world, however, for the Witch King also leverages the secret recipe of the elixir that Malus requires to suppress the Daemon that possesses him.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: As Malus prepares to return to Naggaroth aboard his Black Ark it seems that Clan Eshin have other plans and have gathered to intercept him. The recent murderous attentions of the assassin-brood had not been as random and as senseless as they appeared – it is the Daemon they want, but they must know as well as Malus does that they are going to have to kill him to get it. Malus had heard of the ratman assassin Deathmaster Snikch, but now has the feeling that he may be about to get much more closely acquainted with him…

The ranks of the Ruinous Ones were no easy feat to bring down. Norscans, Beastmen, the warhost of disciples from the Chaos Wastes itself – all the twisted Chaos-things which drew their immense strength from beyond the void, from the very realm of Chaos itself. This was the strength which Snikch’s master craved.

The location of the great power was finally revealed to Snikch through the words of the Chaos warhost’s Sorcerer, who had vainly attempted to bargain for his own release. “You are a fool, ratling peon,” the Sorcerer shrieked, “for the power you seek is a Daemon of Slaanesh, and no minor Daemon at that! Tz’arkan, the Drinker of Worlds, is a ravenous monster inextricably bound to the soul of a living entity. The only chance of severing the Chaos-imbued bond is to destroy the vessel in which the Daemon is trapped. That vessel is none other than the Druchii known as Malus Darkblade.”

The prospect of wielding the power of a Daemon suddenly sounded very good to the Deathmaster. Almost as soon as he’d ordered his spies to find Darkblade’s location, word returned that the Druchii tyrant was in the area, but about to board his Black Ark back to Naggaroth. He cannot be allowed to escape!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: This place is a dangerous maelstrom of disorder, haunted by myriad horrors that blight the land. A provincial foothold should first be gained before this holy errantry war can be seen through to its conclusion.

“Promise death to these worthless peons. They have no other value than to breathe their last on the end of a blade. As their lifeforce ebbs away, so too shall mine grow. This is your path to unimaginable power, and mine to freedom...”

“Blood must be spilled, in copious quantities, and with the cruellest of blades, for the greater the suffering, the more we will be feared. And feared we must be, for it will render us unstoppable. Go forth and sow destruction...”

“There is no finer sensation than to take an innocent life. Imagine, then, how delectable it would be to fell a city. Bring them doom, o cage of mine. Feed my hunger, let me take control. I guarantee you will enjoy it...”
Through its herald, you have issued a challenge of battle to Shackolot the Calamity. The ancient Black Dragon and its attendants shall fight without mercy to test our strength!

localised_title: Dragon Battle: Bruwor, Protector of Life
localised_description: Through its herald, you have issued a challenge of battle to Bruwor, Protector of Life. The ancient Forest Dragon and its attendants shall fight without mercy to test our strength!

localised_title: Dragon Battle: Lamoureux the Frozen Breath
localised_description: Through its herald, you have issued a challenge of battle to Lamoureux the Frozen Breath. The ancient Moon Dragon and its attendants shall fight without mercy to test our strength!
Through its herald, you have issued a challenge of battle to Ymwrath the Eternal. The ancient Star Dragon and its attendants shall fight without mercy to test our strength!

localised_title: Dragon Battle: Gordinar, Champion of the Flame
localised_description: Through its herald, you have issued a challenge of battle to Gordinar, Champion of the Flame. The ancient Sun Dragon and its attendants shall fight without mercy to test our strength!

You have accepted the Food Merchant’s cooking challenge! River Hags may not be fussy eaters, but neither are they particularly good communicators. Should Grom manage to work out what in the name of Mork n’ Gork that the Hag is demanding, there will be rewards…

Grom had been guilty of resting on his laurels in the past, especially when the spoils of war (and the ensuing victory banquets) were particularly good. If it had not been for the sinister encouragement of his power-crazed Shaman Ol’ Blacktoof, Grom’s ambitions may not have always been backed up by his actions, and he certainly wouldn't have gotten off his corpulent rump to lead Broken Axe’s first invasion of Yvresse. Unfortunately, Blacktoof eventually had his head lopped off by that pointy-‘eaded git Eltharion, but before that had absorbed copious amounts of power from destroyed Waystones. So much power, in fact, that it made him rather difficult to actually be killed, even after having his head severed from his body.

Before Grom had given up on rallying his fleeing troops from Tor Yvresse, he’d spotted his Shaman’s head on the ground shrieking angry obscenities at him, so he put it in a jar before fleeing himself. Since that day, Blacktoof’s head mostly spurted unintelligible nonsense – being devoid of a body can do that to an Orc. Recently, however, he started saying things that grabbed Grom’s attention, claiming that he knew how to get the Waaagh! going again. The first thing he suggested Grom do, however, is throw a feast to motivate the ladz.

Never turning down an excuse for a banquet, Grom bellows to them to grab some scrap to get the cauldron fire going, and now!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Grom’s minions collected enough scrap to set Misty Mountain on fire. As the cauldron bubbled away, Niblet, eager to get the banquet started, scurried off to return with a hefty amount of a rather strange foodstuff of unfathomable origin, although Blacktoof’s head assured everyone that it was actually edible.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: As Grom and the tribe stuffed their faces around the banquet fire, Blacktoof’s head started blabbering once again, excitably exclaiming his great plan to get the horde together and go back to Tor Yvresse. It was obvious that the bitter Shaman was after some long overdue revenge on the Warden himself, the glint of the Elven general’s sword being the last thing the Shaman saw before his untimely decapitation. Grom was too distracted to think about the crazy Shaman’s personal vendetta, since he had his own motivations to return to the pointy-'eads' glittering city. He'd long dreamt of sailing back there to have another good scrap, but this time claiming the metropolis as his greatest prize – and of course, holding the banquet to end all banquets in his own triumphant honour!\n\nBefore Grom could shove a bit more of the cooked carrion into his massive gob, Blacktoof’s head drew his attention to a Food Merchant who had shown up nearby in the lumbering form of a Troll Hag. Grom couldn’t immediately figure out how, but the Shaman suggested that perhaps the Troll Hag could help them. In any event, Grom was always enticed by the possibility of sinking his teeth into any new, exotic things the Food Merchant might sell him.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The Food Merchant was not particularly aggressive towards Grom and the ladz, though they still regarded her as being rather odd, even by Greenskins standards. What annoyed Grom the most was the fact that she really didn’t have as much food to sell him as he wanted. Sharing his frustrations for some mysterious reason, Blacktoof’s head assured him he could still get his hands on more food ingredients to fill his increasingly distended belly, and that it would help the tribe’s ruinous cause. As usual, Grom didn’t understand the Shaman’s motives or ends, but wasn’t going to disagree with his advice, especially when it would result in even more grub entering his huge gob.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description:
Grom was getting restless. Back when Blacktoof was still in one piece he had helped Broken Axe to countless victories, but now all he seemed to want Grom to do was eat. The obese Goblin King wouldn’t usually have a problem with that, except a day spent eating was no different to any other day, and he failed to see how it would get him to the gates of Tor Yvresse.

Niblet showed up to tell him that the Shaman’s head was doing some strange things, spinning around in its jar with its eyes glazed over. Blacktoof was in one of his trances, an event which usually led to a prophecy. When the head finally stopped spinning, it gazed upon Grom with its familiar, evil glare. The Shaman said that although making the crossing would be much easier this time, getting across Ulthuan's soil and into the city would not be. He had seen that the pointy-‘ead Warden had used every method possible to reinforce his realm’s defences, the walls of the city built thicker, the blanketing mists more lethal than ever. Luckily for them, by channeling the power he'd sapped from the ruined Waystones, Blacktoof had worked out the precise limitations of the mists’ power. Every time Grom feasted, his waistline, strength, and battle prowess would grow, eventually reaching a point when he would be able to penetrate the murk.

To get to the gates of Tor Yvresse, then, Grom needs only to keep eating as many different dishes as he can!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: With the Broken Axe tribe marching in his wake, Grom had eaten his way across the world to become fatter and stronger than he’d ever been. Blacktoof’s head cackled within its jar as it beheld the Goblin King’s huge, distended paunch. The time had come, Blacktoof’s prophecy had come to pass. Grom was ready to lead the tribe through the inimical mists to the gates of the prized city of Tor Yvresse, expecting Eltharion to be there to give him the fight to end all fights. The city, Yvresse and all of Ulthuan would soon be Grom’s!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Trust in yer magic cauldron, yer immensity! Invest in its power! It will help ya on yer path to greatness!
Glory lies in ruination, o’ paunchy one! Da pointy-‘eads lands will bring ya da most loot n’ battle glory!
Ya outgrew Misty Mountain long ago, yer corpulence! Make a kingdom worthy of da tribe, worthy of da Goblin King!

Your journeys have taken you far from Caledor, and so your control over affairs in the Court of Dragons has waned. A faction of nobles, callow fools with little respect for Caledor’s martial heritage, has inveigled their way into the halls of power. The fragmentary reports you receive from your homeland tell of a land fallen to dissolution and indolence, where nobles revel in luxuriant balls even while vicious pirates ravage the coast.\n\nSuch behaviour might be fitting of an Avelornian, but Caledor is a land of warriors – this cannot be tolerated! You must find ways to contact and mobilise your allies at home before action can be taken.

Grom marched through the Yvraine Plain where the Elves had made a futile stand against him all those years ago. This time, they cowered within Tor Yvresse. Grom found himself salivating – possibly because he hadn’t eaten in the last ten minutes, but mainly at the thought of conquering the pointy-‘eads great city at long last. Eltharion, the Elf-git who repelled his first invasion and beheaded his Shaman, would be waiting for him. Grom was going to chop him up and burn the city to the ground, just in time for dinner.

As Eltharion reconnoitred Grom’s great horde from Tor Yvresse’s walls, his grip involuntarily tightened on his Fangsword. The city’s defence against the Goblin King’s insatiable attentions is his sworn duty, just as it was his father’s before him. But this was personal. He suddenly remembered that Grom’s first invasion had caused the deaths of his family members, his brother grislily hacked apart by the obese Goblin himself. Today, duty and vengeance would both be accomplished. There would be no escape for the Paunch.

Following Throt’s repeated attacks upon the Waystone sites in Naggaroth, Ariel has begun her ritual in the Witchwood! From the moment Clan Moulder had learned about the Mage Queen’s plans, Throt wondered how such a juicy tip-off could so conveniently land on his lap, but assumed it had something to do with the forest-things’ squabbles amongst themselves. It matters little to him now – with Ariel’s powers focused on her ritual, she is exposed, giving Throt the chance to finally obtain the greatest specimen he will likely ever get his foul claws on. By his haphazard calculations, consuming the demigoddess’ life essence will not only cure his extreme case of the Black Hunger, but could also make him more powerful than he could ever imagine. Moreover, after having his fill who knows what delightfully horrible things he can create in his laboratory using the leftover Queen-pulp? The possibilities are endless!\n\nAs purported by the tree-thing informant, Ariel should be vulnerable while she performs her ritual, but will not be unprotected. She will undoubtedly have her strongest lieutenants defending her, so Throt must fill his ranks with Moulder’s most dangerous monsters to ensure nothing can stop him from claiming Ariel as his prize.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Though the Great Vortex stifles Daemonkind, a rift in the Witchwood provides Chaos with another passageway into the world. Ariel, demigoddess of the Asrai and avatar of Isha, channels all her power to seal the portal, hoping to prevent the Daemons of the Dreaming Wood from entering the mortal plane. Somehow, the scheming Skaven know the Mage Queen is vulnerable, and are preparing to attack. The Sisters of Twilight must dispatch them before they can disrupt Ariel’s efforts and bring cataclysm to the world.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: In the current age, the Wood Elves and their Tree Spirit allies have been known to offer their assistance to the lesser races who dwell outside the boundaries of Athel Loren for the good of the Weave. Some Bretonnians came to look upon your kind as allies, even bestowing honourary Knighthoods unto your commanders for coming to their aid in battle. The Dwarfs, however, have been somewhat more stubborn in forgetting the times long past when Wood Elf hosts defeated them in battle, even though such events ostensibly occurred due to their own greed and crude ignorance. Despite your kin's efforts to right those perceived wrongs, the Dwarfs have never once considered striking an entry against the fey folk from the Book of Grudges in thanks. The great treeman Elder Durthu has grown weary of their discourtesy and could become a valuable ally should you decide to punish them.

The fey folk do not take kindly to those of their own who turn their backs on Athel Loren. To do so is not only to forsake their kin, but the very Weave itself. Many Asrai know the tale of Oreon, a Glade Prince who one day decided to assemble a band of the forest’s best archers and woodsmen before setting sail to fight far from the great forest in the Elves' Southlands campaigns. Though Oreon himself has not been seen or heard of in many centuries, his band and their descendants are known to still reside far away on the desert continent as mercenaries-for-hire. Such an existence is frowned upon, and for some time there has been whispers throughout the glades demanding these skillful Elven warriors return to fulfil their obligations to the forest. Such is the warriors code, however, that the only way to bring them back under Athel Loren’s influence would be to defeat them in honourable battle!

The relationship between the Asrai and the Tree Spirits is highly complex and oft tumultuous. Cooperation was only ever possible due to a shared cause to be stewards of the forest; a task too often made all the easier by the alliance. Yet it is still desirable to some of the forest that the Wood Elves be decimated by war, most of all Drycha, the Briarmaven of Woe. As with all Tree Spirits, her loyalty is to the forest first and foremost, but she is also closely associated with Coeddil, the malevolent Ancient guilty of committing heinous crimes against the Asrai. To go to battle against the Wood Elves is to garner Drycha’s favour. For the purposes of strengthening the Weave, she could be a powerful ally indeed.

Nestled in the northern reaches of the Empire is Loren’s sister-colony of Laurelorn, an enclave of Wood Elves that also endured the ages since Ulthuan withdrew its colonies from the Old World. The Empire states of Nordland and Middenland have historically both claimed Laurelorn Forest as their territory, but due to the fiercely isolationist Asrai who inhabit it, none have ever tried to enforce such claims. Lately the Empire has been the least of the Laurelorn Elves’ worries, as the Sea of Claws has seen increasingly frequent crossings by bloodthirsty Norscans whose sole purpose is war and destruction. Recent Northmen raids have seen them gain ground further south into Nordland, bringing Marauder bands closer to Laurelorn Forest. Minor skirmishes have already occurred, with Asrai blood needlessly spilt. For the good of the Weave, defeating the Norscans in battle and weakening their numbers may facilitate a friendship with the Laurelorn Elves and make them more sympathetic to your cause.

The Worldroots are important to all, for the fate of the Oak of Ages that sprouted them governs the fate of all forests, and some say the fate of the entire world. Few are more aware of this than the Sisters of Twilight, who use the ancient pathways by the will of their beloved Mage Queen Ariel. Lately it has been reported that the activities of the scheming, skittering Skaven have caused damage to the Worldroots. The ratmen gnaw at them not only making them untraversable in places, but also rendering all who use them vulnerable to Skaven ambushes. Bringing the Skaven to war and defeating them in battle will send a message that the defilement of the Oak of Ages’ sacred roots will not be tolerated. Furthermore, such actions will be seen favourably by the Sisters of Twilight, whose battle prowess and association with the powerful Mage Queen would make them very useful allies indeed.

Ariel and Isha have long been one and the same, their desires merged into a single whole. Orion’s personality, however, is a melding not only of Kurnous, but also of the last Elf whose flesh was chosen to bear Kurnous’ spirit. The one selected by the Wild Riders on the eve of the last vernal equinox was a particularly combative individual, whose love for warmongering in the forest’s defence was said to exceed that of any his peers. With that in mind, it will take little more than some displays of martial prowess to garner the approval of the current manifestation of the King in the Woods, who could become a most valuable ally.

The history between men and the folk of Athel Loren has always been a tumultuous one. Though the affairs of the earlier primitive man-tribes had been seen as folly by the Asrai, in more recent times the kingdom of Bretonnia to the west has grown in importance, acting as a buffer against the many threats the forest has had to face. Sometimes the ignorant men who live at the forest’s fringes take unpermitted sustenance from it, with such transgressions always met with the rage of a Wild Hunt that brings swift and merciless death. Lord Daith, ruler of Torgovann, has recently been vocal about the fact that the balance of power between Bretonnia and Athel Loren must be reinforced, for although these men can be considered friends, they are also inferiors and need to be reminded of that fact. A display of force against them will certainly show Lord Daith that you do not shirk from such responsibilities.

The Pine Crags is an embattled region, ever beset by the Greenskins of the Grey Mountains. As such, beneath Wydrioth’s eaves are a maze of walkways, root-braced tunnels, and outposts of living defence-works that have repelled many an opportunistic Waaagh!. Lord Findol who holds sway over the realm has a thirst for battle matched only by his courtiers, taking great joy in slaughtering the green menace who so frequently intrude upon his domain. After seeing off a recent rash of particularly large Greenskins attacks, however, the realm is slightly less defensible than it has been in the past. Lord Findol has reached out to you asking for your assistance – he would like you to bring war to the Greenskins so that their attentions may be elsewhere while Wydrioth’s defences are rejuvenated. Though he has little fear that any Greenskins attack would succeed even now, he prefers for his glades to be fully primed to inflict maximum bloodshed for the inevitable future attacks.

So far separated from the rest of my subjects, your position is uniquely vulnerable. So too am I, left in Karak Azul without the aid of my greatest Runelord. As we stand defiant against the threat of the vile Greenskins and the repulsive Skaven scourge, it's clear that our strength must be combined if we are to withstand their advances and ensure the great Hold of Karak Azul does not fall.

Some betrayals run so deep as to transcend the veil of death itself. Such was the treachery of the Lord Malekith, whose solemn oath of friendship to the Dawi — sworn at his dearest friend's deathbed — has been broken a hundred times over! Grombrindal will not forget. The villainous Dark Elves must pay for their deceit, and only then will this most grievous of betrayals finally be avenged!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The filthy Greenskin hordes of Grimgor Ironhide have ravaged the fortresses of the Dawi long enough! This insolence will not go unpunished. Grimgor's baleful deeds have been recorded in the Dammaz Kron, and the time has come to exact retribution!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The events of the War of Vengeance has been long resigned to the annals of history, yet the memory of its horrors lives on. So many fallen Dawi cannot be ignored. Though time has cast its shadow over their loss, the High Elves must be reminded that the Dawi do not forget, and we will not forgive!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Any loathsome, degenerate creature vile enough to be known as the Dwarf-Smiter is worthy of their entry in the Dammaz Kron. This reeking rodent is no more than a belligerent thorn in the side of all Dawi, whose armies must be crushed under heel.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The so-called King under the Mountain is yet to pay for the litany of transgressions he has committed against the Dawi. Every brave warrior lost at the Battle of the Jaws must be avenged with the blood of the Crooked Moon Tribe!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Through cowardly cunning and subterfuge, the loathsome creature Snikch has shed Dawi blood time and again. Drag him out from the shadows in which he lurks and let him know he cannot hide from our vengeance!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The Ancestors must rage to see the repulsive creature Throt threatening our great strongholds. Any victory his pestiferous armies have won over our brave warriors must be repaid in kind, with Dawi valour and steel!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Ever since the valiant King Vikram Ironside was defeated, our once great Hold of Karak Drazh has been infested with the vile stink of endless Greenskin hordes. The brave sacrifice of Vikram and his men must be avenged. Storm the gates of the Black Crag and see that the hold of Karak Drazh is finally reclaimed!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The burned ruins of Karak Azgal, where the Dragon Graug once made his nest, now host a scourge of Goblins and Skaven, who reside amidst the glories of our history. The time has come to eradicate them all and finally restore Karak Azgal to our people!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Lurking in the darkness of Red Eye Mountain, the Night Goblins make their quarters in the halls that should be home to our people. Reclaim Karak Ungor, and strike this grudge out once and for all!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The Daemonic forces of Chaos have long flooded the halls of Karak Vlag; it is time this wrong is righted. We must at last cast out these usurpers and take back what is rightfully ours!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The mines of Mount Gunbad have been lost to us for centuries, yet the precious brynduraz they contain is a resource much too valuable to leave untapped. The Night Goblins infesting the area must be eliminated!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: An infestation of reeking ratmen burrow beneath the once prosperous mine of Mount Silverspear. Our pride dictates we take it back, exacting retribution on those that would steal what is ours, and erasing the shame of our forced retreat along the Silver Road.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The cunning and devious Lahmians drove us from Silver Pinnacle, and their treachery will be repaid with blood and steel! Their deeds are recorded in the Dammaz Kron and will not be forgotten until the day the Dawi rest in the mountain once again.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Grimnir the Fearless is the patron of warriors. These exotic Beard Rings masterfully crafted in his name once belonged to one of his deadliest Slayer Clerics but have long been lost. Should they be recovered, the Slayers of the Brotherhood of Grimnir will be left with only the reason for their oaths of which to feel ashamed.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Grungni, the mighty Allfather of the Dawi, taught our Ancestors the very skills that have assured our survival for centuries. This pick is a holy relic crafted in his honour by the oldest of the Dawi, and the Longbeards will not be appeased until it is recovered.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: This keepsake once belonged to a mighty warrior who sought to eradicate defilers of the dead in the name of the Lord of Underearth, Gazul himself. Its loss has been a subject of great shame said to be felt even by the Ancestors, whose souls will not be appeased until it is back in Dawi hands.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: The goddess of the hearth, healing and brewing, Valaya once bestowed great gifts upon the Ancestors so that we could assist our fellow Dawi in need. There is no doubt that all Dwarfkind will be greatly boosted by the return of these powerful items.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: By Morgrim's teachings, the craftsmanship displayed with these sacred gears, legendary paradigms of Dwarfen engineering, are of the highest echelons. The knowledge set by their standard is sacred, so the revered instruments must be recovered and preserved for future generations of Dawi.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: In his time, Raton proposed dangerous and radical ideas to gain control over primitive beasts. With the help of the Engineers' Guild, he developed a prototype collar that apparently worked, but was slain while binding it to a beast subject. Now long lost, this item’s efficacy could further prove Dwarf engineering’s supremacy over magic.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: It is no doubt that Smednir’s smelting techniques made us the most renowned metalworkers in the world. Many of his most important formulae were lost during the many upheavals of the Dwarfen dynasties, likely stolen by those without understanding of what they took. Without Smednir’s lost secrets, the Dawi can never be as great as they are destined to be!
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.

localised_description: Thungni’s Tongs were utilised by some of the first Runesmiths under his tutelage, serving them well in crafting the most potent rune-weapons ever made. These powerful armaments were crucial in many of the great victories of our kin – such weapons could be forged again, but not without the tongs that gave them their power, long lost in the mists of time.
localised_mission_completed_text: Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
Success! You have achieved one of your goals.
